repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Allow C functions/variables with names starting with "__" to be found
from within classes, even though their names would normally be
inaccessible due to the Python "class private names" mechanism.
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3544

Where globals are looked up by name (e.g. with error_on_unknown_names =
False) make sure to lookup the mangled name

comment_data.body: Hmmm … not … beautiful. Can't we handle this with scope recursion somehow, instead of letting the Scope base class know how and when to mangle Python names or not? I mean, it's ok if a class scope knows that it can look up a name in different ways. Other scopes shouldn't have to care.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -919,17 +920,33 @@ def find_imported_module(self, path, pos):
                 return None
         return scope
 
-    def lookup(self, name):
+    def lookup(self, name, _no_mangle=False):

comment_data.body:
I think if we handled with scope recursion then:

```
cdef int __var = 1
cdef int _A__var = 2

class A:
  class B:
    def get_var(self):
      return __var
```

would end up returning `_A__var` instead of `__var` because after `B` fails to find the name it'd then let `A` have first go.

Maybe that's behaviour's OK? It isn't obvious to me either way.

I'll have a look and see if it can be done better, but the challenge is we can have multiple classes with an opinion about mangling in the chain. In Python only the "current" class gets to decided, and my inclination says it should be the "current" class or no mangling at all.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -919,17 +920,33 @@ def find_imported_module(self, path, pos):
                 return None
         return scope
 
-    def lookup(self, name):
+    def lookup(self, name, _no_mangle=False):

comment_data.body: Is `A` even in the `parent_scope` chain of `B`? AFAIK, that's not how class scopes work in Python. They do not nest.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -919,17 +920,33 @@ def find_imported_module(self, path, pos):
                 return None
         return scope
 
-    def lookup(self, name):
+    def lookup(self, name, _no_mangle=False):

comment_data.body: You're right. This can be (and now is) done much cleaner
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -919,17 +920,33 @@ def find_imported_module(self, path, pos):
                 return None
         return scope
 
-    def lookup(self, name):
+    def lookup(self, name, _no_mangle=False):

comment_data.body: Hmm, is it possible that a scope declares both a mangled and an unmangled double underscore name? Like a `cdef extern` C name and a Python variable with the same name, only the latter of which gets mangled now?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -922,20 +923,44 @@ def find_imported_module(self, path, pos):
     def lookup(self, name):
         # Look up name in this scope or an enclosing one.
         # Return None if not found.
-        name = self.mangle_class_private_name(name)
-        return (self.lookup_here(name)
-            or (self.outer_scope and self.outer_scope.lookup(name))
-            or None)
+
+        mangled_name = self.mangle_class_private_name(name)
+        entry = (self.lookup_here(name)  # lookup here also does mangling
+                or (self.outer_scope and self.outer_scope.lookup(mangled_name))
+                or None)
+        if entry:
+            return entry
+
+        # look up the original name in the outer scope
+        # Not strictly Python behaviour but see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3544
+        entry = (self.outer_scope and self.outer_scope.lookup(name)) or None
+        if entry and entry.is_pyglobal:
+            self._lookup_python_mangled_warning(entry.pos, name)
+        return entry
 
     def lookup_here(self, name):
         # Look up in this scope only, return None if not found.
+
+        # if the name is already declared in the scope then return it, even if
+        # mangling should give us something else. This is to support things like
+        # global __foo which makes a declaration for __foo

comment_data.body: This method doesn't do a lookup, it emits a warning. The name should reflect that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -987,6 +1012,11 @@ class FakeOperand(Node):
         operands = [FakeOperand(pos, type=type) for type in types]
         return self.lookup_operator(operator, operands)
 
+    def _lookup_python_mangled_warning(self, pos, name):
+        warning(pos, "Global name %s matched from within class scope "
+                            "in contradiction to to Python 'class private name' rules. "
+                            "This may change in a future release." % name, 1)

comment_data.body: Hmm, this is still done in the base class. Why not in `ClassScope`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+                or None)
+        if entry:

+
+        # look up the original name in the outer scope

comment_data.body: Yes - this looks the wrong way round. Fixed now.

comment_data.body: I don't think it can be. `mangle_class_private_name` mangling uses `parent_scope` (so in a typical case will start in a function local scope, then go up to class scope. `lookup` uses `outer_scope`, so would typically jump from a function local scope to a module scope (and not involve the `ClassScope`)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -922,20 +923,44 @@ def find_imported_module(self, path, pos):
     def lookup(self, name):
         # Look up name in this scope or an enclosing one.
         # Return None if not found.
-        name = self.mangle_class_private_name(name)
-        return (self.lookup_here(name)
-            or (self.outer_scope and self.outer_scope.lookup(name))
-            or None)
+
+        mangled_name = self.mangle_class_private_name(name)
+        entry = (self.lookup_here(name)  # lookup here also does mangling
+                or (self.outer_scope and self.outer_scope.lookup(mangled_name))
+                or None)
+        if entry:
+            return entry
+
+        # look up the original name in the outer scope

@@ -121,3 +121,43 @@ without actually calling it, e.g.
 
     # Explicitly disable the automatic initialisation of NumPy's C-API.
     <void>import_array
+
+Class-private name mangling
+===========================
+
+Cython has been updated to follow the `Python rules for class-private names
+<https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/classes.html#private-variables>`_
+more closely. Essentially any name that starts with and doesn't end with 
+``__`` within a class in mangled with the class name. Most user code
+should be unaffected -- unlike in Python unmangled global names will
+still be matched to ensure it is possible to use access C names
+beginning with ``__``:
+
+::
+
+     cdef extern void __foo()
+     
+     class C: # or "cdef class"
+        def call_foo(self):
+            return __foo() # still calls the global name
+            
+What will no-longer work is overriding methods starting with ``__`` in
+a ``cdef class``:
+
+::
+
+    cdef class Base:
+        cdef __bar(self):
+            return 1
+
+        def call_bar(self):
+            return self.__bar()
+
+    cdef class Derived(Base):
+        cdef __bar(self):
+            return 2
+
+Here ``Base.__bar`` is mangled to ``_Base__bar`` and ``Derived.__bar``
+to ``_Derived__bar``. Therefore ``call_bar`` will always call 
+``_Base__bar``. This matches established Pythoon behaviour and applies

commit.message:
Relax class private names for c types

Allow C functions/variables with names starting with "__" to be found
from within classes, even though their names would normally be
inaccessible due to the Python "class private names" mechanism.
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3544

Where globals are looked up by name (e.g. with error_on_unknown_names =
False) make sure to lookup the mangled name
Handle global __var and cleaned up code
Fixed ordering of fallback, renamed function

Further simplification

mangle_special_name didn't need to be different from
mangle_class_private_name, and meant that slightly different rules
applied for creating vs looking up variables

Removed __pyx special case (no longer needed)

Global __pyx_ symbols are now found through the fallback anyway

Revert "Removed __pyx special case (no longer needed)"

This reverts commit 1626810f88ce1a4eb9d7b20fc85031bf427a6c4a.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Relax class private names for c types
